name: Lua
description: Lua's original ANSI C interpreter.

name: LuaJIT
description: High-performance Just-In-Time compiler for Lua.

name: LLVM-Lua
description: Compiles Lua to LLVM.

name: lua.vm.js
description: Lua VM on the web; a direct port of the C interpreter via LLVM, emscripten, and asm.js.

name: Moonshine
description: A Lua VM implemented in JavaScript. Slower than lua.vm.js, but with better docs, examples, and JS interfacing.

name: MoonSharp
description: A Lua interpreter written entirely in C# for the .NET, Mono and Unity platforms.

name: UniLua
description: A pure C# implementation of Lua 5.2, focused on compatibility with the Unity game engine.

name: lupa
description: Python bindings to LuaJIT2.

name: golua
description: Golang bindings to the Lua C API.

name: GopherLua
description: Lua 5.1 VM and compiler implemented in Go with Go APIs.

name: LuaRocks
description: Allows you to install Lua modules as packages called "rocks", which contain version and dependency information. Much like npm or pip.

name: MoonRocks
description: Public Lua rock repository, website, and uploading tool. Default server used by LuaRocks.

name: ProFi
description: Simple profiler that works with LuaJIT and produces a report file.

name: luatrace
description: Toolset for tracing/analyzing/profiling script execution and generating detailed reports.

name: StackTracePlus
description: Drop-in upgrade to Lua's stack traces which adds local context and improves readability.

name: MobDebug
description: Powerful remote debugger with breakpoints and stack inspection. Used by ZeroBraneStudio.

name: lovebird
description: Browser-based debug console. Originally made for LÖVE, but works in any project with LuaSocket support.

name: Lua Development Tools
description: Eclipse plugin which provides code completion, debugging, and more. Built on Metalua.

name: Lua for IDEA
description: IntelliJ IDEA plugin which, among other things, provides code completion, smart highlighting, and experimental debugging.

name: ZeroBraneStudio
description: Lightweight, customizable, cross-platform Lua-dedicated IDE with code completion and analysis, written in Lua. Has broad debugging support for numerous Lua engines.

name: Babelua
description: Lua editor/debugger, extension for Visual Studio 2012/2013. Has code highlight, auto-completion, syntax checking and formatting, file previewing, debugging capabilities integrated into Visual Studio.

name: Lua Fun
description: High-performance functional programming library designed for LuaJIT.

name: Moses
description: Functional programming utility belt, inspired by Underscore.js.

name: Penlight
description: Broad, heavyweight utility library, inspired by Python's standard libs. Provides the batteries that Lua doesn't.

name: lua-stdlib
description: Middle-weight standard library extension; adds some useful data structures, utility functions, and basic functional stuff.

name: Microlight
description: A little library of useful Lua functions; the 'extra light' version of Penlight.

name: LÖVE 2D
description: Desktop game development platform. Cross-platform, feature-complete, well-adopted.

name: Corona SDK
description: Development platform for iOS and Android. Proprietary, but used by numerous top games and apps, totaling over 150 million downloads.

name: MOAI
description: Open source, cross-platform, mobile game development framework. Minimalist C++ engine powered by Lua scripting.

name: Drystal
description: Open source, games can run on Linux or on any platform with a recent web browser.

name: Amulet
description: Open source, audio/visual toolkit suitable for small games and experimentation. It runs on Windows, Mac, Linux, HTML5 and iOS.

name: gengine
description: A 2d game engine for fast development, using entities and components system, for Linux, Windows and HTML5.

name: Coronium.io
description: Simple cloud platform supporting analytics, data objects, user management, and more.

name: awesome-love2d
description: A list like this one, but focused on game dev and the LÖVE platform.

name: lurker
description: Shortens the iteration cycle by auto-swapping changed Lua files in a running LÖVE project.

name: HUMP
description: A set of lightweight helpers for LÖVE; a game-oriented utility belt.

name: moaifiddle
description: Edit and share short scripts for the MOAI game engine and run them in the browser using WebGL.

name: Jumper
description: Fast, lightweight, and easy-to-use pathfinding library for grid-based games.

name: lume
description: Utility belt library geared toward game development.

name: NoobHub
description: Network multiplayer for Corona, LÖVE, and more, following a simple pub-sub model.

name: bump.lua
description: Minimal rectangle-based collision detection which handles tunnelling and basic collision resolution.

name: HardonCollider
description: Detect collisions between arbitrarily positioned and rotated shapes of any type.

name: flux
description: A fast, lightweight tweening library for Lua with easing functions and the ability to group tweens together.

name: tween.lua
description: Small library for tweening, with several easing functions.

name: termtris
description: A tetris clone, written in literate style with "an emphasis on learn-from-ability".

name: PacPac
description: A Pac-man clone, made with LÖVE.

name: Mari0
description: Fusion of Mario and Portal, made with LÖVE. See also its wikipedia entry.

name: Journey to the Center of Hawkthorne
description: 2D platformer based on Community's Digital Estate Planning episode, made with LÖVE.

name: log-lua
description: Asynchronous logging library with pluggable writers for filesystem, network, ZeroMQ, and more.

name: OpenResty
description: A fast and scalable web application platform created by extending Nginx with Lua. Today's de-facto Lua web platform, used heavily by Cloudflare, Taobao, Tencent, and others.

name: turbo
description: Event-driven, non-blocking, LuaJIT-based networking suite and framework, inspired by Tornado.

name: Kepler Project
description: A collection of web-oriented projects using a common set of standards and components.

name: Pegasus.lua
description: Pegasus.lua is a http server to work with web applications written in Lua language.

name: awesome-resty
description: A list like this one, but focused on OpenResty.

name: ngx_lua
description: The core piece of OpenResty. Embeds Lua in Nginx and exposes, among other things, the cosocket API for non-blocking sockets (compatible with LuaSocket's API).

name: OpenResty GitHub Organization
description: Home of the repositories for ngx_lua, ngx_openresty, and many related modules.

name: lua-resty-http
description: Lua HTTP client driver, built on the cosocket API.

name: Lapis
description: Full-stack framework for Lua and OpenResty. Like the Django or Rails of Lua. Supports Moonscript.

name: ledge
description: Lua module providing scriptable, RFC-compliant HTTP cache functionality.

name: Sailor — An MVC web framework compatible with OpenResty, Apache and other webservers.
Kong
description: Microservice & API Management Layer

name: ansicolors
description: Simple function for printing to the console in color.

name: cliargs
description: A simple command-line argument parsing module.

name: lua-term
description: Terminal operations and manipulations.

name: argparse
description: A feature-rich command line parser inspired by argparse for Python.

name: Lumen
description: Simple concurrent task scheduling.

name: ConcurrentLua
description: Implements an Erlang-style message-passing concurrency model.

name: llthreads
description: A simple wrapper for low-level pthreads & WIN32 threads.

name: lanes
description: Library implementing a message passing model with one OS thread per Lua thread.

name: luaproc
description: Message-passing model which allows multiple threads per OS thread and easily generalizes across a network. See also the paper where it originated.

name: lustache
description: Mustache template implementation.

name: etlua
description: Embedded Lua templates, ERB-style.

name: lua-resty-template
description: Lua-oriented template engine for OpenResty, somewhat Jinja-like.

name: LDoc
description: Documentation generator which modernizes and extends LuaDoc.

name: Locco
description: Lua port of Docco, the "quick-and-dirty, hundred-line-long, literate-programming-style documentation generator".

name: docroc
description: Parse comments into a Lua table to generate documentation.

name: 30log
description: Minimalist OOP library with basic classes, inheritance, and mixins in 30 lines.

name: middleclass
description: Simple but robust OOP library with inheritance, methods, metamethods, class variables and mixins.

name: LuaFileSystem
description: Extends and complements Lua's built-in set of filesystem functions.

name: luaposix
description: Bindings for POSIX APIs, including curses.

name: LuaDate
description: Date and time module with parsing, formatting, addition/subtraction, localization, and ISO 8601 support.

name: cron.lua
description: Time-related functions for Lua, inspired by JavaScript's setTimeout and setInterval.

name: magick
description: Lua bindings to ImageMagick for LuaJIT using FFI.

name: LuaFFT
description: An easy to use Fast Fourier Transformation package in pure Lua.

name: Worp
description: Sound/music/DSP engine written for LuaJIT.

name: eLua
description: Lua, extended with optimizations and specific features for efficient and portable embedded software development.

name: SciLua
description: Numerical/scientific computing framework built on LuaJIT, with an interface to R.

name: Torch7
description: Scientific computing framework with wide support for machine learning algorithms, used by Facebook, Google, and more.

name: lhf's Lua Tools
description: Assorted libraries and tools, many math-related.

name: lua-cjson
description: Blazing fast JSON encoding/decoding implemented in C and exposed to Lua.

name: luajson
description: JSON encoder/decoder implemented in Lua on top of LPeg.

name: dkjson
description: JSON encoder/decoder implemented in pure Lua.

name: LuaExpat
description: SAX XML parser via binding to the Expat library.

name: SLAXML
description: Pure Lua SAX-like streaming XML parser.

name: lyaml
description: YAML encoding/decoding via binding to LibYAML.

name: LPeg
description: A pattern-matching library for Lua, based on Parsing Expression Grammars.

name: lunamark
description: Converts Markdown to other textual formats including HTML and LaTeX. Uses LPeg for fast parsing.

name: i18n.lua
description: Internationalization library with locales, formatting, and pluralization.

name: inspect.lua
description: Human-readable representation of Lua tables.

name: serpent
description: Serializer and pretty printer.

name: Ser
description: Dead simple serializer with good performance.

name: lua-zlib
description: Simple streaming interface to zlib for gzip/gunzip.

name: lua-zip
description: Lua binding to libzip. Reads and writes zip files.

name: LuaCrypto
description: Lua bindings to OpenSSL.

name: lua-lockbox
description: A collection of cryptographic primitives written in pure Lua.

name: luatweetnacl
description: Bindings to tweetnacl, modern high-security cryptographic library.

name: LuaSocket
description: Networking extension which provides a socket API for TCP and UDP, and implements HTTP, FTP, and SMTP.

name: lua-websockets
description: WebSocket client and server modules. Webserver-agnostic, implemented in Lua on top of LuaSocket.

name: LuaSQL
description: Simple interface for connecting to ODBC, ADO, Oracle, MySQL, SQLite and PostgreSQL.

name: redis-lua
description: Pure Lua client library for Redis.

name: pgmoon
description: Lua PostgreSQL driver for OpenResty and others.

name: lua-resty-mysql
description: Lua MySQL driver for OpenResty.

name: lua-resty-redis
description: Lua Redis client driver for OpenResty.

name: lua-resty-cassandra
description: Lua Cassandra client driver for OpenResty and others.

name: busted
description: BDD-style unit testing framework with great docs and Moonscript support.

name: telescope
description: Flexible and highly customizable testing library.

name: luassert
description: Assertion library extending Lua's built-in assertions.

name: lust
description: Minimal test framework.

name: LuaJIT FFI
description: LuaJIT's mechanism for calling external C functions and using C data structures from pure Lua code.

name: luaffi
description: Standalone FFI library, compatible with the LuaJIT FFI interface.

name: luadec51
description: Lua Decompiler for Lua version 5.1.

name: luacov
description: Simple coverage analyzer, used by busted and telescope for checking test coverage.

name: luacheck
description: Simple static analyzer which detects accidental globals and undefined or shadowed locals.

name: Metalua
description: Pure Lua parser and compiler, used for generating ASTs. A number of other tools make use of the Metalua parser in this way.

name: LuaInspect
description: Lua's most powerful code analysis and linting tool, built on Metalua. Used by ZeroBraneStudio, among others.

name: LuaMinify
description: Minifier which also brings its own static analysis tools, lexer, and parser.

name: Typed Lua
description: A typed superset of Lua that compiles to plain Lua.

name: punchdrunk.js
description: Moonshine + LÖVE API reimplementation = run LÖVE games in the browser.

name: luvit
description: Node.js's underlying architecture (libUV) with Lua on top instead of JavaScript.

name: graphql-lua
description: Lua implementation of GraphQL.

name: luakit
description: Fast, small, webkit based browser framework extensible by Lua.

name: Hammerspoon
description: A powerful, extensible OS X automation tool. A community-maintained fork of Mjolnir.

name: kpie
description: A scripting utility to juggle windows.

name: lumail
description: A console-based mail client, with extensive scripting capabilities.

name: AwesomeWM
description: A highly configurable and extensible window manager for X, scripted and configured by Lua.

name: Textadept
description: Extremely lightweight, customizable, cross-platform editor, written (mostly) in (and scripted by) Lua.

name: KoReader
description: An ebook reader application supports PDF, DJVU, EPUB, FB2 and much more, running on Kindle, Kobo, PocketBook and Android devices.

name: MoonScript
description: Moonscript is a dynamic scripting language that compiles to Lua. It reduces verbosity and provides a rich set of features like comprehensions and classes. Its author calls it 'CoffeeScript for Lua'.

name: sitegen
description: A static site generator which uses MoonScript and supports HTML and Markdown, page grouping, and plugins.

name: Reference Manual
description: The official definition of the Lua language.

name: lua-users wiki
description: A large community-maintained collection of Lua information and resources, supplementing the official website.

name: Lua Unofficial FAQ
description: Answers all sorts of Lua-related questions, including many of the form 'How to ___?'.

name: lua-l
description: The official Lua mailing list, and one of the focal points of the Lua community.

name: Lua 5.3 Glossary
description: A glossary of some essential Lua terms.

name: Lua-users style guide
description: A general, high-level style guide; unopinionated, easily agreed on.

name: Olivine style guide
description: A more opinionated and specific, and therefore more rigorous, guide.

name: Lua Crash Course
description: Short crash course readover, or reference for when you forget the basics.

name: Learn Lua in 15 Minutes
description: A well-commented example file which covers the basics.

name: Learning Lua from JS
description: An overview of the similarities and differences between Lua and JS; a great start for JavaScript folks looking to pick up Lua.

name: lua-users tutorial
description: In-depth collection of tutorials aimed at newcomers.

name: Lua Missions
description: A series of 'Missions' to work through which are designed to teach aspects of Lua along the way.

name: Creating an Image Server
description: Walks through setting up and using OpenResty to build a simple image processing server; a great starting point for playing with OpenResty.

name: Embedding Lua in C
description: An introductory walkthrough of embedding Lua in a C program. A bit dated, but still a great walkthrough.

name: Lua: Good, bad, and ugly parts
description: A thorough summary of the good, different, bad, and ugly aspects of Lua, including many subtle quirks, by the author of ZeroBraneStudio.

name: Lua states, libraries, coroutines and memory
description: Diagrams and explains some more advanced concepts of the Lua VM, particularly when interfacing with C.

name: Roberto's Talks
description: History of talks given by Lua's chief architect, with slides for each.

name: Lua Workshop Talks
description: High-quality talks are given at each ~annual Lua Workshop, and a history of them is online, slides included.

name: Programming in Lua
description: The authoritative intro to all aspects of Lua programming, written by Lua's chief architect. Three editions released; first edition available online.

name: Programming Gems
description: A collection of articles covering existing wisdom and practices on programming well in Lua, in a broad variety of use cases.

name: Lua Programming
description: A shorter overview of the language, up to date for Lua 5.2, and available online.

name: awesome-resty
description: A list like this one, but focused on OpenResty.

name: awesome-love2d
description: A list like this one, but focused on game dev and the LÖVE platform.

name: awesome-lua by @forhappy
description: Another list similar to this one. It goes into more depth in a few categories, but has less breadth.

name: Where Lua is Used
description: A comprehensive list of stand-alone programs written in or extensible using Lua.
